body: It does seem to make sense that we only ever want to click enabled buttons, to be honest. I don't think we should have a separate `click_enabled_button` action though. I'm torn about this. @joliss, what do you think?
Seems reasonable to me to change the default behavior of click_button/click_on to exclude disabled buttons.
How about something like `fill_in` then? If we disallow it in one place, we should disallow it everywhere, right?
Good point. The problem applies to anything that can be disabled, really.
Yes, looks like the XPaths for all [form interaction methods](http://rubydoc.info/github/jnicklas/capybara/master/Capybara/Node/Actions) would have to be updated.

issue.title: Possible race condition when clicking an element that has js bound to it

repository.name: capybara
repository.description: Acceptance test framework for web applications

issue.body:
The problem I'm having is similar to issue #771 only my buttons are not disabled but have behavior(form submission) bound to it via javascript.   

My tests are passing intermittently thus leading me to believe I'm hitting a race condition.  

I'm thinking that capybara is clicking on the button and some of the time not all of the javascript  files have loaded(due to cpu and/or io conditions) and so I'm clicking on a button that isn't submitting the form and thus my test fails.  

When I switch my driver to Selenium/chrome-webdriver, it seems to pass much more consistently, but still fails from time to time.  In fact, when it fails with selenium/chrome, I can see it try to click the button while the browser is still loading...

So the question is, does capybara wait until all asset files(js, css, img) are loaded before attempting to click on or interrogate the response?

body:
@synth, I'm not sure if your problem is related to this. I also have stumbled upon issues where Capybara has simulated user actions before dynamic javascripts has been loaded. I solved it by extending my step definition which navigates the browser.

``` ruby

Given /^(?:|I )am on (.+)$/ do |page_name|
  page_url = $config[:host] + path_to page_name

  unless browser.current_url.include? page_url
    browser.visit page_url
    browser.wait_until do
      browser.evaluate_script "Ext.isReady"
    end
  end
end
```

You get the gist, right? I'm sure there's something equivalent in RequireJS.

@badeball you're a genius!  this has solved the remaining funky issues I was having!  I created a helper to handle the various ui cases that I needed to wait for: 

https://gist.github.com/3292441

@synth Re your gist, you can implement wait_until_overlay_has_popped_up without resorting to evaluate_script by doing something like this (assuming RSpec; untested):

```
page.should have_css('.div.overlay', visible: true)
```

It will wait for the element to appear. For the other method, analogously with have_no_css.

issue.title: Pressing a disabled button in a form results in form submission

repository.name: capybara-webkit
repository.description: A Capybara driver for headless WebKit to test JavaScript web apps

issue.body:
I am testing a disabled button on a form and pressing it with capybara-webkit (0.13.0). It results in form submission. I verified with Firefox 16.0 and Safari 6.0.2 that don't actually trigger the submit event.

``` html
 <button disabled="disabled">Search</button>
```

issue.title: Capybara 2
issue.body:
This one is trickier. The first two commits (disabled buttons and an unrelated doc fix I made along the way) are easy. The third, which lets us raise an error if the locator is ambiguous, is more work.

Part of it is the field tests. The example form view contained two scopes with "First name" and "Last name" fields, and a lot of tests that referred to them suddenly had errors. Rather than rewrite all those tests, I removed the second scope. Then I created a second form view, which _does_ have both scopes, just for the tests that actually _use_ scopes. I also wrote some new tests for the `AmbiguousField` error.

The rest of it is detailed in the commit message; I had to flag an ambiguous case that Capybara doesn't recognize.

body:
I agree that you never want to press a disabled button, but it can be useful to `find` one  you may actually want to verify that a button is present but not enabled.

I don't personally have a use case for this right now, I just ran across it while updating Kelp. I'm just bringing it up for (belated) discussion.

From [Kelp](https://github.com/wapcaplet/kelp)'s perspective, the problem of disabled-button invisibility appears to be due to [this xpath commit](https://github.com/jnicklas/xpath/commit/a8f970d0f) made at around the same time as the above fix; I'll open an issue over there with the details. (Edit: see [xpath issue #47](https://github.com/jnicklas/xpath/issues/47))

Regarding a use case for this, I would put forward the example where a "Save" button is dynamically enabled or disabled depending on user actions within a form. For instance, a Cucumber scenario might say:

```
  When I leave a required field blank
  Then the "Save" button should be disabled
  When I fill in all required fields
  Then the "Save" button should be enabled
```

I agree with the above, that it doesn't make much sense to click a disabled button, but even if a button (or other form element) is disabled, it still _exists_, and is _visible_.
I am a newer. I want to verify if a button is disabled, how to do it?
How can we do this now that `wait_until` has been removed? My JS is loaded asynchronously with require and Capybara gets there before the assets are loaded... (I can use `sleep` but that's lame)

@adamwaite, given that Capybara is simply a fast user, one can assume that a regular user with a slow connection might experience similar troubles when actuating on your site before assets has finished loading asynchronously. How would you solve that? You could for instance output buttons in a disabled state and enable them with Javascript, thus forcing a user to wait until it has loaded. Or you can query some other element that you know will change once that the Javascript has loaded.
ah yes, good thinking. That's given me some new ideas to try out tomorrow. Thanks.
